content.title: Endarterectomy
content.definition: Endarterectomy is the surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from within an artery by creating a cleavage plane in the media, removing the diseased intima and inner media, and leaving a smooth residual lumen.

principle.concept: Direct removal of obstructing plaque rather than bypass around it
principle.cleavage_plane: Between outer and inner media (media splits)
principle.endpoint: Smooth transition to normal intima, often tacked down or patched

femoral.name: Common femoral endarterectomy (CFE)
femoral.indication: CFA disease, inflow procedure, complement to bypass

aortoiliac.name: Aortoiliac endarterectomy
aortoiliac.note: Less common now with endovascular options and bypass

plaque_elevation.distal_endpoint: Critical - must feather down or tack to prevent dissection

closure.primary: For large vessels with good diameter
closure.patch: Most common for CEA - vein, bovine pericardium, or synthetic

eversion_technique.concept: Transect artery, evert vessel like taking off sock, remove plaque
eversion_technique.advantage: No patch needed, theoretically removes less redundancy

endpoints.visual_inspection: Smooth transition, no loose intimal flaps
endpoints.intraoperative_imaging: Duplex, angiography, or angioscopy to confirm

complications.hemorrhage: From suture line or disrupted branches
complications.nerve_injury: Particularly for CEA (hypoglossal, vagus, marginal mandibular)

vs_bypass.endarterectomy: Removes plaque, preserves native anatomy, single site disease
vs_bypass.bypass: Circumvents disease, for long segments, poor inflow/outflow

adjuncts.shunting: Maintains flow during procedure (CEA - used selectively or routinely)

learning_objectives: Describe the principle and cleavage plane of endarterectomy
List common applications of endarterectomy technique
Compare conventional longitudinal vs eversion technique
Identify key technical points including endpoint management
clinical_pearls: Cleavage plane is in the media - leaves outer media and adventitia
Distal endpoint management is critical to prevent dissection flap
Patch closure reduces restenosis after CEA
Eversion CEA eliminates need for patch but requires vessel transection
